name: realignment
content:
realignment noun [C or U]
(CHANGING IDEAS)
Add to word list
Add to word list
the process of changing your ideas or policies so that they are the same as those of another person or group; the result of this process: This war will inevitably lead to a realignment of/within European politics. The presidential election could play an important role in the state's realignment.
More examplesFewer examplesAmerican voters are in the middle of a major realignment.The company will not reveal the full scope of its manufacturing realignment for several months. The financial crisis is likely to cause a radical realignment of the global economy.

realignment noun [C or U]
(CHANGING POSITION)
the act of putting something, or the fact of being put, into a new or correct position, or an instance of this: She had undergone a nose job and a chin realignment. The plan called for the realignment of streets in the area.
More examplesFewer examplesShe underwent surgery for a pelvic realignment earlier this year.Even a relatively minor realignment of Greenwood Lake Turnpike has been immersed for years in the red tape of preliminary planning.The movement or realignment of a body part to its normal position is known as reduction.

ECONOMICS the process of changing the value of a currency compared to the value of other currencies or of changes in interest rates: Most people in Europe would be happier if the burden of the dollar's realignment were shared more evenly.realignment of sth Realignments of exchange rates can be potentially disruptive. currency realignment
